title: 104_hr2439
content: The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" allows states to use infrastructure banks for financing transportation projects, providing more flexibility in developing public-private partnerships. Congress recognizes the need for new financial concepts in transportation programs that traditional federal reimbursement programs cannot accommodate. The "State Infrastructure Banks Act of 1995" defines key terms like Secretary, State, and State infrastructure bank. State infrastructure banks are created to finance transportation projects at the state or multi-state level. Congress grants consent to States to establish State infrastructure banks and enter into interstate compacts to promote regional investment in transportation infrastructure. State infrastructure banks can provide loans, issue debt, and offer assistance to entities constructing transportation projects. State or State infrastructure banks can provide loans, issue debt, and offer assistance to public or private entities for transportation projects eligible for financial aid under title 23, United States Code. A State infrastructure bank can provide financial assistance for transportation projects under title 23, United States Code. This assistance can include loans or other forms of support for the construction or capital costs of qualifying projects, with the option to subordinate the assistance to other project financing. The Act allows for financial assistance, such as loans, to cover construction or capital costs of transportation projects. This assistance can be subordinated to other project financing and includes various forms of support like credit enhancements and bond issuance financing. The State infrastructure bank can use funds for credit enhancements, capital reserves, bond issuance costs, insurance, subsidizing interest rates, and other approved leveraging tools. States must maintain an investment grade rating for debt issuances to qualify. To qualify as a State infrastructure bank, participating States must maintain an investment grade rating on debt issuances or have sufficient insurance. Investment income generated by deposited funds must be credited to the bank for providing loans and other purposes. The State infrastructure bank must have a sufficient level of bond or debt financing instrument insurance to maintain viability. Investment income from deposited funds must be credited to the bank, available for loans, and invested in Treasury securities or other financing instruments for interest. The State infrastructure bank must have insurance for bond or debt financing instruments to remain viable. Investment income from deposited funds is credited to the bank and can be used for loans, invested in Treasury securities or other financing instruments for interest. Repayment of loans or assistance to a State can be credited to the bank or used for the same purposes as the loaned funds under title 23. The State infrastructure bank must have insurance for bond or debt financing instruments to remain viable. Investment income from deposited funds is credited to the bank and can be used for loans, invested in Treasury securities or other financing instruments for interest. Repayment of loans from the bank will commence not later than 5 years after the facility has opened. The State infrastructure bank must ensure that loaned funds are available under Title 23, with repayment starting within 5 years of project completion. The loan term should not exceed 30 years, and the amount loaned should not exceed the state's transfer amount. The State infrastructure bank must ensure that loan terms do not exceed 30 years, limit loan amounts to the state's transfer amount, and provide annual reports to the Secretary on its status. The Secretary must ensure that federal disbursements for capital reserves are consistent with historic rates for the Federal-aid highway program and establish procedures for State infrastructure banks under this Act. Contributions from Title 23 apportionments are limited to the amount transferred by the State. Annual reports on the bank's status must be submitted to the Secretary by September 30 each year. The State infrastructure bank must ensure federal disbursements are in line with historic rates for the Federal-aid highway program and establish procedures for operation. States can transfer up to 15% of Federal funds apportioned under specific sections of Title 23 to the bank. A State can transfer up to 15% of Federal funds apportioned under specific sections of Title 23 to a State infrastructure bank. The disbursement rate should not exceed the traditional rate for the Federal-aid highway program. The United States is not obligated to deposit Federal funds. A State can transfer up to 15% of Federal funds apportioned under Title 23 to a State infrastructure bank at a disbursement rate not exceeding the traditional rate for the Federal-aid highway program. The deposit of Federal funds into a State infrastructure bank does not create any obligation on the part of the United States to any third party. The deposit of Federal funds into a State infrastructure bank does not create any obligation on the part of the United States to any third party. Funds used as a capital reserve under this Act are not subject to certain management regulations. State infrastructure bank clarifies that the security or instrument is not a commitment, guarantee, or obligation of the United States. Sections 3335 and 6503 of title 31, US Code do not apply to funds used as a capital reserve. States can contribute up to 2% of Federal funds deposited into the bank for administrative costs.
